title: Wales Leads U.K. Property Price Growth
text:
Property price growth in the U.K. showed slight signs of improvement in August, recovering from the seven-year low registered in the previous month, according to a report Wednesday from the government’s Land Registry.



The 1.3% increase left the average home price in the U.K. at £234,853 (US$301,648), according to the index published by HM Land Registry and the U.K. government’s Office for National Statistics, along with other U.K. government statistics agencies.

Though minimal, the rise was an improvement on July's dismal 0.7% increase.



The report did not break out data for the luxury market.



Price growth across the nation was led by Wales, as has been the case each month since last November, according to the data.



The country saw average property prices pushed up 4.5% in August to £168,318. In Scotland, average prices rose 1.6% to £154,549; while England—which is typically home to almost 80% of the U.K.’s real estate transactions—saw prices edge up 0.8% to £251,233.



The report only provided data for Northern Ireland’s quarterly prices and found average prices increased 3.5% to £136,767 in the second quarter compared to the same time last year.

“The closer we come to an apparent EU exit, the more likely it is that even the most fearless home buyer or seller will hold tight until the dust has settled, and so further downward trends should be expected until the start of next year at the very least,” said Marc von Grundherr, director of estate agency Benham and Reeves, in an email statement.



On a more local level, London was one of only two regions to see prices drop in August, falling 1.4% to £472,753. In the South East of England values fell 0.6% to £326,232.



Prospective London buyers who are currently waiting on the sidelines for some clarity around Brexit “would do well to strike while the iron is, well uncertain, as we will only see market values strengthen as time goes on,” Mr. von Grundherr said.
